content: I started a tracking issue for the translation process. We could continue our previous policy of offering the survey in any language we get translations for, but this ignores the additional overhead of coordinating translation. Would love people's feedback on this issue: https://github.com/rust-lang/surveys/issues/5

Seems good. Also keep in mind that answer choices will need to be different for specific regions. For example, for communication channels, since Discord is totally unavailable, Zulip and Github are partially unavailable in China. The major instant-communication choices will be QQ, Wechat and Lark. It's ok to leave the unavailable options in the survey, but be sure to add the major options :)

I don't think the answer options should be different - it makes it hard to compare answers. Also, we shouldn't assume things like that - I use WeChat and I'm outside China, and I'm sure some people in China are using Discord - the GFW is pretty permeable if you have the inclination :-) However, you are correct that we should not limit our answers to the English language defaults.
Yes, those choices were manually added by the Simplified Chinese translation team in the past. Please make sure to include them in the mainline survey then.

Regarding the yes/no translation effort for some languages, I now have a tiny feedback from the Italian Rust Slack channel. It's not a huge community but it's one of the main gathering point where Rust developers and Rust-curious people hang out.

10 days ago I've started a poll asking whether the Rust survey translation was an added value or not. The response - in absolute numbers - was very small (it's also full holiday season in Italy) but in relative numbers the preference leans overwhelmingly to keeping it.
screenshot-20210813-141558.png

My guess about this response is that many can fluently /read/ technical English but find more difficulties /expressing/ nuanced thoughts in English; the Italian survey adds a proxy to fix this.

It's an effort that in a way complements the welcoming traits of the Rust community (i.e. we don't do it because the numbers make it worth but because we keep in high regard minorities/underrepresented/etc. communities).

Anyway, take this feedback for what it's worth. In case the Italian language will be kept, I volunteer to handle it from start to finish like in the past 2 years (if no one else jumps in). But I'm also personally ok if in the end some languages will be dropped.
(psst ... don't tell anyone but I personally fill in the English survey anyway :laughing:)

We will be starting the translation process again soon. If you are interested in translating, please let me know. If you have worked with us last year, you'll be getting an email from me soon. We will be translating the following languages:
